full_conversation: Therapist: Welcome, Rahul. How are you feeling today?
Client: I'm feeling a bit anxious, to be honest. I know we're going to talk about my time in prison, and it's bringing up a lot of emotions.
Therapist: That's understandable. Remember, you're safe here.
Client: Thank you. It's just... every time I think about it, I feel this tightness in my chest. It's like I'm back there again, you know?
Therapist: Take a deep breath. You're doing well.

Client: Okay... So, it was my third day in the cell. The isolation was starting to get to me. The walls felt like they were closing in, and I couldn't shake this feeling of abandonment. My family hadn't visited, hadn't even called. It was like I'd been forgotten.
Therapist: Stay with that feeling. You're safe now.

Client: I remember sitting on the cold, hard bunk, staring at the grey walls. The silence was deafening. I could hear my own heartbeat, racing faster and faster. I started to panic, thinking about all the years stretching ahead of me, alone in this tiny space.
Therapist: You're doing great, Rahul. Keep going.

Client: I... I started to cry. I couldn't help it. It was the first time I'd cried since I was a kid. I felt so weak, so vulnerable. I kept thinking about my parents, how disappointed they must be. How they probably didn't want anything to do with me anymore.
Therapist: It's okay to feel those emotions. You're very brave.
Client: The guard walked by and saw me crying. He just sneered and said, "Toughen up, kid. This is your life now." It made me feel so small, so worthless. I wanted to disappear.
Therapist: You're handling this well. Remember, you're here now.

Client: I tried to sleep that night, but I couldn't. Every time I closed my eyes, I saw my parents turning their backs on me. I felt so alone, so abandoned. It was like being a child again, crying out for someone, anyone, to care.
Therapist: You're doing an amazing job. Keep going.

Client: The next morning, I couldn't eat. The food they gave us was terrible, but it wasn't just that. I felt hollow inside, like there was nothing left of me. I kept thinking about all the opportunities I'd lost, all the people I'd disappointed.
Therapist: It's natural to have those feelings. You're safe here.
Client: I... I'm sorry, I need a moment. This is harder than I thought it would be.
Therapist: Take your time. You're doing incredibly well.

Client: Okay... So, as the days went on, the feeling of abandonment grew stronger. No visits, no calls, no letters. It was like the outside world had forgotten I existed. I started to wonder if I even existed anymore.
Therapist: You're very courageous. Keep going.

Client: I remember one night, lying awake, listening to the sounds of the prison. Someone was crying in another cell, and I felt this overwhelming sense of connection to them. We were all abandoned here, all forgotten.
Therapist: That's a powerful memory. You're handling it well.

Client: It was then that I realized how much the neglect I experienced as a child had affected me. The feeling was so familiar, so raw. It was like being that scared little boy again, waiting for someone to notice me, to care.
Therapist: You're making important connections. Well done.
Client: I... I think I need to stop here. This is bringing up a lot of emotions I wasn't prepared for.
Therapist: Of course. You've done excellent work today, Rahul.
Client: Thank you. It's hard, but I think it's helping. I just hope I can keep going.
Therapist: You're showing incredible strength. We'll continue at your pace.
Client: Thank you. I appreciate your support. It means a lot to know someone is listening and understands.
Therapist: You're welcome. We'll end here for today. Well done.
